question: Question_02_(b)
sols:
We can evaluate this limit directly. We start by evaluating what happens
to $\sin x$ and $\cos x$ as $x \to 0^+$. Because this is a directional
limit from the right, we will have $\sin x \to 0^+$ (on a sine graph, as
you approach \emph{x = 0} from the right, the \emph{y} value is
approaching zero \emph{from above}, hence approaching $0^+$) and
$\cos x \to 1^-$ (similarly, approaching \emph{x = 0} from the right on
a cosine graph means approaching \emph{y = 1} from below, hence $1^-$).
Replacing $\sin x$ with \emph{y} and $\cos x$ with \emph{z}, we can thus
rewrite the limit as a fraction of the limits:

\begin{align*}\lim_{x \to 0^+} \frac{\ln(\sin x)}{\ln(\cos x)} = \frac{\lim_{y \to 0^+} \ln(y)}{\lim_{z \to 1^-} \ln(z)}\end{align*}

Again, the fact that this is a directional limit means that for the
first limit, as $y \to 0^+$, $\ln(y) \to -\infty$ and for the second
limit, as $z \to 1^-$, $\ln(z) \to 0^-$. So we have:

\begin{align*}\frac{\lim_{y \to 0^+} \ln(y)}{\lim_{z \to 1^-} \ln(z)} = \frac{-\infty}{0^-}\end{align*}

Recall that when a function goes to zero from the left in the
denominator, this means that we eventually divide by a very small
negative value (for example, -1/100000). Using fraction rules, this very
small value in the denominator is the same as multiplying by a very
large negative value (in my example, -100000) in the numerator. Thus
going to zero in the denominator corresponds to multiplying the
numerator by a very large number. Since our numerator is already going
to negative infinity, the fact that we have $0^-$ in the denominator
will make the value of the limit greater, and turn it back from negative
to positive. Thus the value of this limit is $+\infty$,

\begin{align*}\displaystyle
\lim_{x \to 0^+} \frac{\ln(\sin x)}{\ln(\cos x)} = +\infty\end{align*}
hints:
Try evaluating the limit directly. Pay attention to the directional
limit - the fact that this is a right hand limit will impact the sign of
your answer.
